misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays magically stay linked when one is sorted
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because `studentNamesArray` and `studentScoresArray` represent the same real-world students, sorting the `scores` array will automatically keep the corresponding `names` in the same relative positions (i.e., the 'link' between arrays persists without explicitly moving names).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent memory structures. `Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray)` reorders only the integers in `studentScoresArray`. It does not and cannot automatically rearrange `studentNamesArray` to match, because the sort has no knowledge of any intended pairing. To keep parallel arrays aligned, you must swap elements in both arrays together during sorting, or (better) store name+score together in an object and sort those objects.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints a name that does not actually belong to the highest score unless the input already happens to be ordered to match the sorted scores).

evidence.code_snippet:
// Now we sort the scores array so that the highest score ends up at the end
// I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray);

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because two arrays logically represent the same data (names paired with scores), sorting one array will automatically maintain the correspondence with the other array. The student thinks that after calling Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray), the names array will magically reorder itself to stay aligned with the scores.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent data structures. Calling Arrays.sort() on one array does not affect other arrays. The student has a mental model where logically-related data structures are somehow 'linked' or 'synchronized,' but Java does not provide this automatic coupling. When you sort the scores array, the names array remains in its original order, breaking the pairing between names and scores.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program will produce incorrect output. For the sample input, after sorting scores [85, 92, 78] into [78, 85, 92], the code will access studentNamesArray[2] which is 'Charlie' (the third name), but the highest score 92 belonged to 'Bob'. Output will be 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)'.

evidence.code_snippet: Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray);

String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[highestScoreIndex];
        int topStudentScore = studentScoresArray[highestScoreIndex];

// Now we sort the scores array so that the highest score ends up at the end
        // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that since two arrays are logically paired (parallel arrays), the computer maintains a permanent 'link' between elements at the same index, such that sorting one array will automatically reorder the other to keep the data associated.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to recognize that arrays are independent objects in memory. The Java execution model and standard library methods like Arrays.sort() operate only on the specific reference passed to them; they have no awareness of other arrays that the programmer intends to be 'parallel'.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray);
String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[highestScoreIndex];

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Implicit binding between parallel arrays ("they stay linked automatically")
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because two arrays were filled using the same index (names[i] corresponds to scores[i]), sorting one of the arrays (scores) will keep that correspondence intact, so that the name at the same index still belongs to the sorted score at that index.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, two separate arrays have no automatic relationship. `Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray)` rearranges only the elements inside `studentScoresArray`. It does not (and cannot) also rearrange `studentNamesArray` to match, because Java does not track a "pairing" between elements of two different arrays. To keep parallel arrays aligned, you must swap elements in both arrays together during a custom sort, or (more robustly) store name+score in a single object/record and sort a single list/array of those objects.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed "Top student" name can be unrelated to the highest score (often it will just print the last-entered name paired with the maximum score after sorting).

evidence.code_snippet: // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray);
// Since the arrays are conceptually linked, the last name should match the last score
String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[highestScoreIndex];
int topStudentScore = studentScoresArray[highestScoreIndex];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when you sort one array in a parallel array structure, the relationship between the arrays is automatically maintained. They think that sorting the scores array will keep the names paired with their original scores without needing to explicitly reorder the names array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java does not automatically synchronize parallel arrays. When `Arrays.sort()` is called on `studentScoresArray`, ONLY that array is rearranged. The `studentNamesArray` remains in its original order. After sorting, the indices no longer correspond to the same students. The student's mental model assumes data structures maintain their relationships without explicit code to do so—a violation of how Java actually executes.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program will print an incorrect name for the top student. For the sample input (Alice 85, Bob 92, Charlie 78), the code would output 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the correct 'Top student: Bob (92)', because Charlie is at index 2 in the original names array, but Bob's score is at index 2 after sorting.

evidence.code_snippet:
// Now we sort the scores array so that the highest score ends up at the end
        // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray);

String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[highestScoreIndex];
        int topStudentScore = studentScoresArray[highestScoreIndex];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because two arrays are used to store related data (parallel arrays), they become 'linked' by the runtime environment so that reordering or sorting one array automatically applies the same transformations to the other to keep data pairs together.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are distinct, independent objects in memory with no intrinsic relationship. The 'link' between parallel arrays exists only in the programmer's logic (by accessing them with the same index). Sorting one array via Arrays.sort() does not trigger any corresponding changes in other arrays.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray);
// Since the arrays are conceptually linked, the last name should match the last score
